tips.title: Focus
tips.content: Do not let your mind wander. Your opponent and your sword are the only things.

tips.title: Categorizing your Opponent
tips.content: Do not categorize your opponent’s techniques. There is no time for it.

tips.title: Daring Fox
tips.content: Be aware, but not cautious. The fox who stops to search for the hunter is the most easily tricked. You must train yourself to be empty of doubt.

tips.title: One Step, One Cut
tips.content: There is an exact interval where you or your opponent each must step forward to cut the other. This is what you must learn to see.

tips.title: Stand on the Ground
tips.content: You may step back on your heels or forward on your toes. Either way, you are standing on the ground, and you can cut.

tips.title: Near and Far
tips.content: Do not be at the same distance from your opponent that your opponent is to you. Create a situation where you are closer to your opponent than they are to you. The hands are closer than the head.

tips.title: Watching the Hands
tips.content: To strike, your opponent must move their sword. To move their sword, your opponent must move their hands. Therefore, watch their hands. Caution: do not forget your hands.

tips.title: Opposite Response
tips.content: If you are struck from above, respond from below. If you are struck from below, respond from above. If you are struck from the front, respond from the side. If you are struck from the side, respond from the front. You are at the center.

tips.title: Pine Tree in the Storm
tips.content: Do not match the opponent’s rhythm, and do not set your own rhythm. Be empty: follow no rhythm.

tips.title: Eyes of the Heart
tips.content: Do not watch the opponent with your eyes, but with your heart. The eyes can be distracted, but the heart will not waver.

tips.title: Cutting Down
tips.content: Do not decide to cut, then cut. The decision is useless - there is only the cut.

tips.title: After Cutting
tips.content: There is no previous cut. There is only a next cut.
